briefOverview: Raphael reveals his identity, urges praise of God and righteous living, and departs. The chapter highlights prayer, fasting, almsgiving, and proper gratitude for divine help.
summary: Tobit instructs Tobias to give generous wages to the companion who helped him. When they offer half their goods, the angel takes them aside and exhorts them to praise God publicly and live righteously. He teaches that prayer joined with fasting and almsgiving is good, that a little with righteousness is better than much with unrighteousness, and that almsgiving delivers from death and purges sin. Raphael then discloses that he has presented their prayers before God, witnessed Tobit’s burial of the dead, and was sent to heal Tobit and Sarah. He identifies himself as Raphael, one of seven holy angels who present the prayers of the saints, calms their fear, and attributes all to God’s will. He notes he did not truly eat or drink and commands them to thank God and write down what happened. Raphael vanishes, and they publicly confess God’s great works and the angel’s appearance.
externalContext: Tobit is set among Israelites exiled in Assyrian territory (notably Nineveh) in the 8th–7th centuries BCE, when maintaining Jewish piety under foreign rule could be risky. Practices such as burying the dead reflect Jewish reverence for the body and obedience to Deuteronomic and prophetic ideals of mercy and justice. In Second Temple Judaism, almsgiving became a prominent expression of covenant faithfulness, often linked to atonement and life. The idea of principal angels serving in God’s presence developed in Jewish literature; Raphael’s name appears in some Jewish texts as a healing figure. The Book of Tobit is part of the deuterocanonical/apocryphal corpus: canonical in Catholic and Orthodox traditions, and non-canonical in most Protestant canons.
externalReferences: Raphael’s role in presenting prayers and his identification as one of seven angels parallels Revelation 8:2–4, where seven angels stand before God and incense rises with the prayers of the saints. The triad of almsgiving, prayer, and fasting echoes Matthew 6:1–18, which treats these as core practices of righteousness before God. The claim that righteousness (or almsgiving) delivers from death resonates with Proverbs 10:2 and 11:4, which affirm that righteousness delivers from death, though Tobit states it with an intensified soteriological emphasis.
practicalQuestions: How can I practice generosity and fair compensation toward those who help me?
What concrete habits can join my prayer with fasting and almsgiving this week?
In what settings should I publicly acknowledge God’s help without seeking self-glory?
How might I keep a written record of God’s works to strengthen gratitude and memory?
Where do I need to choose “a little with righteousness” over gain that compromises integrity?
uncertainAreas: The precise meaning and scope of “alms deliver from death and purge away all sin” can be interpreted variously (e.g., temporal deliverance, moral transformation, or eschatological salvation). The identification of the “seven holy angels” invites questions about their correspondence to later named archangels. Raphael’s statement that he did not eat or drink, and that they only saw a vision, raises questions about the nature of his appearance and perception by Tobit and Tobias.
